content: If you copied profile from old pc to new using this process: https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/moving-thunderbird-data-to-a-new-computer then the passwords would also have transferred, and would work if the passwords were not 'app' passwords. I share that for any future similar instances. Although there is no setup for a password change, if the password is failing, you should see a prompt to enter a new one. If the account is POP, the messages do transfer when using the above URL process. To force a prompt, you could go to settings>privacy&security, click savedpasswords and then showpasswords and then highlight the rows for that account and delete them.
creator: davidsk

content: If you are receiving error message for wrong password, then see your email provider for a new one. The password that you may have previously stored in thunderbird is not working.
creator: davidsk

content: It depends. Some email providers, such as Gmail, require an 'app' password that is unique to each PC, while others use the same password everywhere. My general advice is this: when setting up an account DO NOT enter the password until first request for messages and you receive a prompt for it. In most instances, if an app password is required, the email provider will accept your password and will then store a special password for the PC. If an app password is not required, the normal password itself will be accepted and stored on the PC.
creator: davidsk

content:
Step 1: Check Basic Filter Settings Go to Tools > Message Filters.

Ensure the filters are applied to the correct account (POP inbox).

Try setting the filter to run "Manually" and test it by selecting an email and clicking "Run Now".

Step 2: Verify Folder Permissions Check if Inbox and other mail folders are not corrupted.

Right-click the Inbox > Properties > Repair Folder.

Step 3: Delete & Recreate Filters Navigate to Message Filters.

Delete all filters (if they are corrupted).

Create a new test filter (e.g., move messages from a certain sender to a folder).

Run the filter manually to see if it works.

Step 4: Reset Thunderbird's Filter File Close Thunderbird.

Go to:

Mac: ~/Library/Thunderbird/Profiles/your_profile.default/Mail/pop_account/

Find the file msgFilterRules.dat.

Rename it to msgFilterRules.old (backup).

Restart Thunderbird and recreate filters manually.

Step 5: Check Thunderbird Version & Update Go to Help > About Thunderbird and ensure you’re running the latest stable version.

If issues started after an update, consider downgrading to an older, stable version.

Step 6: Test in Safe Mode Start Thunderbird in Troubleshoot Mode (Safe Mode):

Hold the Option key while opening Thunderbird.

Click "Continue in Troubleshoot Mode".

Test if filters work here.

Step 7: Consider Moving to IMAP If POP is unreliable, consider switching to IMAP, which syncs emails better and has fewer corruption issues.

If the issue persists, I’d recommend filing a bug report with Thunderbird’s team (Bugzilla for Thunderbird) or checking their official forums.

content:
Hi David Spector

Please note, if you have used an addon extension or userChrome.css code etc to deliberately hode /alter etc then it's not a bug.

The Message Header buttons do have a 'More' button on the far right that has the 'View Source' There is no mechanism to remove that button in the standard Thunderbird, you can only choose icon or text or both, but not hide.

What would be helpful is if you uploaded an image of what you do see in the Message Header area. So at least we have knowledge of what you are seeing.

You said : "No, none of my addons do this," So please post a list of all addons installed, whether enabled or not. You can find that info here:

  • In Thunderbird
  • Help > Troubleshooting Information
  • Scroll down to 'Addons' section
  • Post an image showing all the data in that section.

Could you be using the addon called Conversations ? If you have installed the addon ' Thunderbird Conversations 4.2.4' Make sure you are using the most up to date as version 4.2.4 Works with Thunderbird 128.0a1 - 134.* https://addons.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/addon/gmail-conversation-view/

That particular addon completely alters the Message Header and you would need to clickon the far right 3 vertical dot icon to see a sub menu and then select the last option 'view message source'

Or did you ever install the addon 'Message Header Toolbar Customize 2.4.4 ' https://addons.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/addon/msghdr-toolbar-customize

That particular addon has an option to 'Hide' a selected button eg: More Right click in the Message Header area on the far right and see if you get the option 'Customise Toolbar'

content:
UPDATE:

I have traced the issue to Norton 360. Seems a recent 'update' to the program has caused the mail protection function to block sending and receiving. Disabling the email protection feature re-enables send/receive functionality.

Next step is to contact them to find out what their plan is to fix the problem.

Hope this helps others who are dealing with the same issue!

content:
Do your other accounts use SSL/TLS or STARTTLS encryption on the connection? Get the certificate and view it to see who issued it. However, I think it will be your third party antivirus, or some of that malware they purport to block it does exactly the same sort of hack to access your encrypted connections.

This is only an issue where encrypted connections are used which is admittedly most major mail providers these days, but some of the older local ISPs and businesses do not use encrypted connections. Generally they use port 995,993 and 465 are used in mail for encrypted connections and 110, 143 and 587 for unencrypted connections.

Port 25 has been reserved for mail relaying, not submission so generally speaking providers will refuse submission on Port 25. It has a long history of being used by consumer malware and really. unless you provider specifically requires it, Port 25 should be avoided.

content:
Para diagnosticar problemas com o Thunderbird, tente uma das seguintes opções:

  • Reinicie o Thunderbird com os complementos desabilitados (Modo Thunderbird Seguro). No menu Ajuda, clique em "Reiniciar com os complementos desativados". Se o Thunderbird funciona normal, há um problema com algum complemento ou tema. Você vai precisar reativar os complementos, um de cada vez, até localizar o infrator.
  • Reinicie o sistema operacional em modo de segurança com rede. Isso carrega apenas o básico necessário para iniciar o computador, permitindo uma ligação à Internet. Clique no seu sistema operacional para obter instruções sobre como iniciar em modo de segurança: Windows 8, Windows 7, Windows Vista, Windows XP, OSX
Se o modo de segurança do sistema operacional corrige o problema, há outro software em seu computador que está causando problemas. As possibilidades incluem, mas não limitados: a digitalização AV, vírus / malwares, downloads em segundo plano, como atualizações do programa.

Se mesmo no Modo de Segurança do Thuanderbird o problema persistir, pode ser que seu problema seja exclusivamente sobre atualização do seu Windows. Neste caso, entre em contato com a Microsoft para obter suporte, basta clicar no link abaixo...

https://support.microsoft.com/pt-br
creator: samuelms79

content:
BoulderRidge said
- We use ESET for virus protection and NordVPN for WIFI security Any comments or advice are greatly appreciated!

I think you might be best served before you consider moving further to disable those two software packages and see if Outlook dies as it has been doing. Most email issues stem from security software. This is especially so with Google who appear to me to look at the location of the IP address used to connect to the server and the one allocated to your mobile phone and then start ringing alarm bells because often they are on different continents.

GMail does have hard limits of the volume of email you can send in a day and the amount of bandwidth that is made available via any single account. Could you husband be exceeding these limits and having Google simply disable further use of the account until the 24hour limit clocks over again. Note that when a provider says you are limited to X number of email per day. A single email addressed to a correspondent and CC'ed to yourself counts as two. A mailing list of 20 or 50 contacts is that many emails, it is the recipients that are counted, not the number of clicks on send.

Likewise sending invoices from accounting packages often also counts to the days total.

Sure Thunderbird is largely feature comparable with Outlook, and simply installing the software and setting the account will allow you to become familiar with Thunderbird. As IMAP is syncronised, the Thunderbird and outlook views of the mail account should be the same, just be aware Outlook has a nasty habit of changing the default mailing program to itself each time it is launched. You can set Thunderbird to check when it is Launched and I strongly suggest you set that up.

Another thing you probably need to be aware of is Thunderbird has native sync of Google contacts and calendars. While you can continue to sync your phones as you do now, Thunderbird can join that synchronized group and also have the same data available. The only thing not synced natively is Tasks, and you say you do not use those anyway. If you do decide to use them, they can be synced with an addon.
creator: MattAuSupport
